reviewText: Perry Mason Season 8 Volume 2These fifteen TV shows from 1965 are based on the novels of Erle Stanley Gardner. The books are more complete and informative, they tell about life that is not experienced by most people. The books explain why some things are done, the films only show you what happened. The books tell you about "ropers", rough or smooth shadows, how to evade surveillance, and avoid leaving a back trail. Some questioned the legality and ethics of Perry Mason's tactics but the stories were written before modern legal rules. The background tells about life in Los Angeles and America. There is nothing like these dramatic stories on today's broadcast TV. When was the last time you saw a trial lawyer as a hero? Erle Stanley Gardner was a founder of the "Court of Last Resort" which sought to free the unjustly convicted. Gardner sought to use scientific means to find the guilty rather than using hunches or guesses alone.The seeming reality of these stories is due in part to characters who don't look like Hollywood actors. Some of the original stories were modified for TV. The theme music is typical for the late 1950s. Note the style of clothing and culture; ladies wore white gloves. People seldom lock their doors. The prices date these films. One advantage is seeing the many automobiles from that era. How many can you identify? Note the slimness of people, the smoking, and the familiarity with pistols. Watch how the actors express their emotions by their facial expressions. The camera sharpness and quality is excellent, but these films have a higher contrast than in earlier seasons. These stories often use the misinterpretation of circumstantial evidence to provide dramatic effects. The courtroom scenes are usually the Preliminary Hearings and often tell about the law. The titles begin with "The Case of The". Most are not from the novels except those with a year after the title."Thermal Thief";  "Golden Venom";"Telltale Tap";  "Feather Cloak"."Lover's Gamble";  "Fatal Fetish";"Sad Sicilian";  "Murderous Mermaid"."Careless Kitten"; (1944)  "Deadly Debt";"Gambling Lady";  "Duplicate Case"."Grinning Gorilla" (1952);  "Wrongful Writ";"Mischievous Doll" (1958).

reviewText: Let me begin by saying I am, and always have been, a tremendous Perry Mason fan. It is with great regret that I see the price that Amazon has given this set.  $50 dollars?  Oh, come on!!!  I buy frequently from Amazon, but this price may force me to look elsewhere.  If I cannot get the set for less, I may be forced to watch for the episodes on television and record them for myself or worst case scenario, do without.  I am sure these episodes are excellent but I gave it 1 star because I feel that someone has gotten greedy and jacked up the price.  How sad.
summary: I'm so sorry Perry!  It's nothing personal.....

reviewText: Perry Mason has been in rerun for forty years. I was pretty convinced I had seen about every episode at least four times, when along comes the second half Season 6, and there are episodes which seem new to me. Perhaps my memory is playing tricks, but I do not think so. These 1965 episodes are less played on cable channels than others.Perhaps the real reason for the minimal play in reruns is Tragg. Ray Collins gets cast credit, but it is Wesley Lau, a fine character actor as the lead homicide detective. Fortunately Della, Paul and Hamilton are in these, but even Perry is absent for one, which is always disappointing.At this stage of the life of the series, the plots are as complex as always, and the outcome is predictable (Perry's client is factually innocent and he gets the real killer to confess in open court). As usual the police charge before fully investigating and Burger's airtight case springs leaks the moment Perry starts cross-examining the first witness.None of this matters. It's Perry Mason. The greatest TV lawyer of all-time. Relax and enjoy.
summary: Some episodes I hadn't seen fifty times

reviewText: Of course $55 is way too much to pay for a half-season. I waited until it was $25.I will edit this after I buy the season in June, so there can be some ACTUAL REVIEWS here, not just gripes that are about Paramount's pricing (Hello! They don't read these.) and not about Amazon, or about the quality of this season !!Update: This is a weird season. Perry is missing in one episode, then has a cast on one arm for a few episodes. Hamilton Burger asks him how his arm feels, but no one bothers to say where/how he hurt it. A ski accident? A hostile witness? A wild night in Vegas? The Case of the Sicilian is one of the worst episodes ever, w/ terrible Italian accents, & Della mooning over the young troublemaker. I really liked the episode set in Hawaii. They used a lot of island scenery & local flavor. Wish they'd done more episodes over there.Perry is beginning to expand in girth, but at least has not succumbed to his Ironside hairstyle yet.Plots are very convoluted (like the Case of the Mermaid), & sometimes Perry doesn't even appear for a half-hour, but still, at its best, PM is one of the best shows ever.

reviewText: Even though I pre-order my dvds, I always expect to see a price decrease on or about the time of release. Not this time. As a matter of fact, the price is still $50.00. what gives Paramount Studios? To add insult to injury, my copy arrived today with a damaged jewel case, a problem I've noticed with Paramount stuff recently,( Mannix the final season),both jewel cases were damaged in the same place indicating a bad packaging machine. Furthermore, it was brought to my attention that the liner notes are incorrect. It's bad enough having the high price,which I can't really afford, let alone all the other flaws. I think Paramount has some explaining to do!

reviewText: There is no way I or any fan of the show should pay this price for 1/2 a season ....of any TV show!!! I have every volume but refuse to pay this price to get this one. IM SORRY..They should be no more than 20-25 per volume and now they are up to 50!!!!!!!!!!!A full season set of a show can run you 40.00 not 100.00 per season. Whoever did this is out of his/her mind and if no one buys it ...watch the price decrease. And to all us folks, as you know we are nearing the end of this series releases (the 9th is the last) so SOON they will be releasing a complete series set and charge a couple hundred dollars for it just to get us to rebuy what we already have..Something has to give with this popular industry. WE CANT BE TAKEN FOR A RIDE LIKE THIS!! In todays economy this has to stop. We know it cant possibly cost this much to get these DVDS released becuase other seasons were under 35!! DONT BUY THIS PEOPLE..If you do, you are feeding right into them!!

reviewText: What can I say about Perry Mason; he's magnificent; he's innovative; he's brilliant and every word that comes out of his mouth is believable and pretty much rocks the boat. The writers have given Raymond Burr the words but Burr has a way of using them that sucks you in and keeps you there throughout each show.I have watched Perry Mason DVD's three times and luckily I have a bad memory (no comment) so when a few years go by I watch them again.  I thought I'd hate black and white and get sick of it but because the stories are so fabulous the black and white scenes are irrelevant and it's the story and acting that is so much fun.If you haven't heard or seen Perry Mason you're in for a treat-a whole world of the 'spoken word' with no blood, no guts, no horrible scenes where you might turn away---just a story and a brilliant team that works with Perry and he and the good guys  ALWAYS GET THEIR MAN (OR WOMAN)!Sherrie H
summary: NEVER GET TIRED OF WATCHING THE KING OF LAWYERS
